title: Documenting reality
brief_description: Documentary has evolved from educational newsreels and public service announcements to the experimental cinéma vérité (‘truthful cinema’), docuseries and online videos. They have also been used to spread propaganda and influence society, projecting interpretations of the truth that highlight the problematic relationship between cinema and reality.

constellations_primary.name: Reality TV me
constellations_primary.description: Cult documentary Grey Gardens follows the everyday eccentricities of mother and daughter Big Edie and Little Edie. The women perform and speak candidly to the camera, and have been described as predecessors to reality TV stars.

description: The very first films could be considered documentaries. Founders of the moving image, like Thomas Edison and the Lumière brothers, captured shorts of real life, called ‘actuality films’, at the turn of the 20th century. In the decades since, documentary has evolved from educational newsreels and public service announcements to the experimental cinéma vérité (‘truthful cinema’), docuseries and online videos. Documentary films have provided insight into others, revealed distant locations and forged deep connections between audiences and stories. But they have also been used to spread propaganda and influence society, projecting interpretations of the truth that highlight the problematic relationship between cinema and reality.
